claim:
Consider the following background information: A 10-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician after discovering a painless mass in the left testicle. Results from tumor markers and a biopsy are as follows: AFP 350 ng/mL (normal value < 10 ng/mL) hCG 0.4 IU/L (normal value < 0.5 IU/L) Biopsy: Presence of glomeruli-like structures with a central capillary within a mesodermal core, lined by flattened layers of germ cells.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: The most likely diagnosis in this patient is Embryonal carcinoma.

supporting.text: The biopsy findings describe glomeruli-like structures, which are characteristic of yolk sac tumor, not embryonal carcinoma.

attacks.text: The biopsy findings describe glomeruli-like structures, which are characteristic of yolk sac tumor, not embryonal carcinoma.
Elevated AFP is highly suggestive of yolk sac tumor, which is consistent with the biopsy findings.
Embryonal carcinoma typically presents with elevated hCG, which is not seen in this case.
Mixed germ cell tumors can have components of both embryonal carcinoma and yolk sac tumor, complicating the diagnosis.
The presence of glomeruli-like structures is pathognomonic for yolk sac tumor, making mixed tumor less likely.

supporting.text: Elevated AFP is highly suggestive of yolk sac tumor, as embryonal carcinoma typically does not produce AFP.

attacks.text: Elevated AFP is highly suggestive of yolk sac tumor, as embryonal carcinoma typically does not produce AFP.
Embryonal carcinoma can occasionally produce AFP, especially in mixed germ cell tumors, which are common in pediatric cases.
The presence of glomeruli-like structures in the biopsy is pathognomonic for yolk sac tumor, not embryonal carcinoma.
Mixed germ cell tumors often show overlapping features, making pure embryonal carcinoma less likely in this case.

supporting.text: The histologic description of flattened layers of germ cells surrounding a mesodermal core is pathognomonic for yolk sac tumor.

attacks.text: The histologic description of flattened layers of germ cells surrounding a mesodermal core is pathognomonic for yolk sac tumor.
The elevated AFP level (350 ng/mL) strongly supports yolk sac tumor, as embryonal carcinoma typically does not produce AFP.
Embryonal carcinoma is more commonly associated with elevated hCG levels, which are normal in this case.
While AFP is a marker for yolk sac tumor, some mixed germ cell tumors may include embryonal carcinoma components with elevated AFP.

supporting.text: Embryonal carcinoma usually presents with elevated hCG, which is not seen in this case (hCG is within normal limits).

attacks.text: Embryonal carcinoma usually presents with elevated hCG, which is not seen in this case (hCG is within normal limits).
Elevated AFP is highly suggestive of yolk sac tumor, which is more common in children and fits the biopsy findings of glomeruli-like structures.
Embryonal carcinoma can still occur without elevated hCG, as hCG elevation is not universal and depends on the presence of syncytiotrophoblastic cells.
The presence of glomeruli-like structures is pathognomonic for yolk sac tumor and not seen in embryonal carcinoma, making yolk sac tumor the more likely diagnosis.

supporting.text: Yolk sac tumor is the most common testicular germ cell tumor in children, whereas embryonal carcinoma is rare in this age group.

attacks.text: Yolk sac tumor is the most common testicular germ cell tumor in children, whereas embryonal carcinoma is rare in this age group.
The biopsy findings of glomeruli-like structures with a central capillary within a mesodermal core are pathognomonic for yolk sac tumor, not embryonal carcinoma.
The elevated AFP level (350 ng/mL) is highly characteristic of yolk sac tumor, which is AFP-producing, whereas embryonal carcinoma rarely produces AFP.
Embryonal carcinoma can rarely occur in children, though it is much less common than yolk sac tumor.
The extremely low incidence of embryonal carcinoma in children makes it statistically improbable compared to yolk sac tumor in this case.

supporting.text: The presence of Schiller-Duval bodies (glomeruli-like structures) on biopsy is diagnostic for yolk sac tumor and excludes embryonal carcinoma.

attacks.text: The presence of Schiller-Duval bodies (glomeruli-like structures) on biopsy is diagnostic for yolk sac tumor and excludes embryonal carcinoma.
Embryonal carcinoma can rarely exhibit Schiller-Duval-like structures, so their presence does not definitively exclude embryonal carcinoma.
The extremely elevated AFP (350 ng/mL) is far more characteristic of yolk sac tumor than embryonal carcinoma, which typically has normal or only mildly elevated AFP.
Mixed germ cell tumors containing both yolk sac and embryonal carcinoma components are common, so the presence of Schiller-Duval bodies doesn't rule out concurrent embryonal carcinoma.
The very low hCG level argues against embryonal carcinoma, which more frequently produces hCG than yolk sac tumors do.
